WRITING.TITLE: Generative Linguistics workshop and discussion with Noam Chomsky and others, streamed live online
WRITING.TEXT:
On Thursday 11 May we will be welcoming a number of renowned linguistics to the University of Reading for a workshop on 'Generative Linguistics in the 21st Century: The Evidence and the Rhetoric', hosted by the School of Psychology and Clinical Language Sciences.
The workshop features a keynote talk by Professor Chomsky and plenaries from 9 other renowned linguists, including Professor Adriana Belleti, Professor Hagit Borer, Professor Stephen Crain, Professor Tanja Kupisch, Professor Terje Lohndal, Professor Luigi Rizzi, Professor Ian Roberts, Professor Ianthi Tsimpli, and Professor Charles Yang. All working on formal linguistic theory and its application to acquisition and processing in children and adult learners. The day culminates in a moderated panel discussion with all our invited speakers, where audience members can ask questions.
The purpose of this workshop is to present and consider the evidence that still points in this direction, while at the same time sifting through and seriously considering the rhetoric that in recent years has rejected the general tenets of generative linguistics. In doing so, we will examine the role of generative linguistics at present and consider where it will be going as the 21st century unfolds.
The entire workshop will be filmed and made available online, but **Professor Chomsky's presentation and the final panel discussion will be streamed live on the University of Reading's Facebook page** from 1530 BST: http://rdg.ac/2pOokcB

WRITING.TEXT:
One of our Classics Professors has a new free online course coming out which might be interesting: http://rdg.ac/FLvirtualrome
He's using his own award-winning virtual model of ancient Rome to show what the city would have been like at its peak, and to try and answer some common questions:
Why was this ancient city built where it was? Did all roads really lead to Rome? How was drinking water supplied to the citys million inhabitants? Where did Romans worship their gods and meet their political masters? And which buildings provided a backdrop for the spectacular events that both celebrated emperors and secured the loyalty of the masses?
He's also keen to take part in an AMA, so let us know if you're interested in talking to him here in the community!
Tim - University of Reading

Whey protein supplement 'significantly' lowers blood pressure and reduces the risk of heart disease and stroke
Whey protein appears to lower blood pressure and cholesterol, reducing risk factors for heart disease and stroke
WRITING.TEXT: [New study](http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/early/2016/10/25/ajcn.116.137919) published in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition investigating whether milk proteins lower ambulatory blood pressure and other risk markers of cardiovascular disease, found significant reductions in blood pressure after whey-protein consumption compared to the control intake.

WRITING.TITLE: Were dinosaurs already dying out before the meteorite hit? Were paleontologists who have just published a radical new theory on dinosaur extinction. Ask Us Anything about meteor strikes, fossils, what this means for modern species, and our favourite dinosaurs.
WRITING.TEXT:
Hi, were /u/DrManabuSakamoto and /u/DrChrisVenditti from the University of Reading in England. Manabu is the lead researcher, and Chris is a co-author, of this paper showing evolutionary decline in dinosaurs long before the meteorite which finished them off.
Read the full paper here: http://rdg.ac/1pbZM9j. Some more info on this paper: http://phys.org/news/2016-04-dinosaurs-decline-asteroid-apocalypse.html
Ask Us Anything about dinosaur extinction, evolution, paleontology, the rise of the mammals. You can find Dr Manabu on Twitter at [@DrMamboBob](https://twitter.com/drmambobob)
Proof: https://twitter.com/UniofReading/status/722782652042903552
UPDATE: We've now signed off for the night and just want to quickly say thank you to everyone for asking so many excellent questions and for having us on /r/AskScience.

WRITING.TITLE: Dinosaurs 'already in evolutionary decline' before asteroid apocalypse which wiped them out
Dinosaurs 'already in decline' before asteroid apocalypse which wiped them out
New study says dinosaurs already in decline before asteroid apocalypse that wiped them out [Article]

WRITING.TEXT: We've got two of the authors from the University of Reading, Dr Manabu Sakamoto and Dr Chris Vendetti, lurking on reddit. Anyone interested in an AMA?
Drs Manabu Sakamoto and Chris Vendetti from the University of Reading are happy to talk to Reddit about their research if there's interest - anyone here like dinosaurs?

WRITING.TITLE: Dinosaurs in decline tens of millions of years before their final extinction

WRITING.TEXT: No problem, the RSC journal says they've waived access costs for articles in 2015 and 2016, so maybe you've only tried to read earlier ones and didn't realise the new ones are free. Hope you get something out of this one, anyway
We're trying something new as a way of sharing interesting research with interested parties. If there's interest in what we've got to share we can always get the academics in to give explanations.
Hi - it's published on the rsc.org website which is [open access and free to read]( http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlepdf/2016/sc/c5sc04864h)
If there's a lot of interest in this new self-healing polymer we can try and get the academics who developed it to pop in for an AMA?

WRITING.TITLE: Polymer repairs itself at body temperature - Royal Society of Chemistry
